questions.stem: Standard 7.06 (Assessing Student and Supervisee Performance) requires that programs providing evaluations of student competence base those evaluations on:

options.text: The student's personality and likability
Relevant and established program requirements that have been communicated to students at the outset
Comparison with other students in the cohort only
A single standardized examination score

questions.explanation: Standard 7.06 requires that evaluations of student and supervisee performance be based on relevant and established program requirements. These requirements must be communicated to students at the beginning of the program. Evaluations should be based on the student's actual performance relative to stated criteria, not personality, peer comparison alone, or a single measure. Programs must use fair and transparent evaluation processes that students are aware of from the start.

questions.stem: According to Standard 7.07 (Sexual Relationships With Students and Supervisees), a psychology professor who is attracted to a graduate student in their program should:

options.text: Pursue the relationship only after the student has completed all courses with the professor
Not engage in sexual relationships with students in their department over whom they hold evaluative authority
Seek consultation from a colleague before initiating the relationship to ensure it is ethical
Disclose the attraction to the department chair to manage the conflict of interest

questions.explanation: Standard 7.07 prohibits psychologists from engaging in sexual relationships with students or supervisees who are in their department, agency, or training center, or over whom the psychologist has or is likely to have evaluative authority. This prohibition recognizes the inherent power differential in educational and supervisory relationships and the potential for exploitation, impaired judgment, and harm to the student's training and career. The prohibition is not limited to current students in the professor's courses but extends to any student over whom they hold or may hold evaluative authority. Consultation does not make an otherwise prohibited relationship permissible.

questions.stem: A clinical training program requires all doctoral students to participate in a minimum of 20 hours of personal psychotherapy before beginning practicum placements. A prospective student inquires about this requirement during the interview process but is told only about coursework and practicum requirements. Under Standard 7.04 (Student Disclosure of Personal Information), this program has:

options.text: Acted appropriately because personal therapy requirements can be disclosed after admission
Violated the standard by not identifying this personal disclosure requirement in admissions materials prior to enrollment
No obligation to disclose the therapy requirement because it is for the student's personal growth
Acted appropriately because faculty have discretion over when to communicate program requirements

questions.explanation: Standard 7.04 states that psychologists do not require students to disclose personal information in course- or program-related activities, either orally or in writing, regarding sexual history, history of abuse and neglect, psychological treatment, and relationships with parents, peers, and spouses or significant others, except if the program or training facility has clearly identified this requirement in its admissions and program materials. By failing to disclose the personal therapy requirement during the admissions process, the program has violated this standard. Students must be informed of all personal disclosure expectations before making the decision to enroll.

questions.stem: A psychology department chair learns that a faculty member has been consistently teaching outdated diagnostic criteria from the DSM-IV rather than the DSM-5-TR in clinical assessment courses. Under Standard 7.03 (Accuracy in Teaching), the department chair should address this because:

options.text: Faculty members have academic freedom to teach any material they prefer
Standard 7.03 requires that psychologists take reasonable steps to ensure that course syllabi are accurate regarding subject matter and the basis for evaluating progress
Students are expected to independently verify all information taught in courses
This is only a concern if students file a formal complaint

questions.explanation: Standard 7.03(a) requires that psychologists take reasonable steps to ensure that course syllabi are accurate regarding the subject matter to be covered, bases for evaluating progress, and the nature of course experiences. Teaching outdated diagnostic criteria when current criteria exist is inaccurate and could harm students' professional development and ultimately their future clients. While academic freedom is important, it does not extend to teaching demonstrably outdated or inaccurate information in a professional training program. The department has a proactive obligation to ensure teaching accuracy, not merely a reactive one.

questions.stem: Standard 7.05 (Mandatory Individual or Group Therapy) addresses situations where individual or group therapy is a program requirement. When a program requires therapy as part of training, which of the following is the most ethically sound approach?

options.text: The faculty member who teaches the student's courses should also serve as the student's therapist for efficiency
Students should be allowed to select their own therapist from practitioners not associated with the program, and therapists should not be in an evaluative role over the student
The program director should assign each student to a specific therapist to ensure quality control
Faculty should be permitted to access therapy notes to evaluate student progress

questions.explanation: Standard 7.05 requires that when individual or group therapy is a program or course requirement, responsible faculty must allow students to select their own therapist from practitioners who are not associated with the program. This protects students from the dual relationship inherent in having their evaluator also serve as their therapist. Faculty who are responsible for evaluating students should not serve as their therapists, and therapy notes should remain confidential. The key principle is protecting student autonomy and preventing the conflation of evaluative and therapeutic roles.

questions.stem: Under Standard 7.01 (Design of Education and Training Programs), psychology programs must ensure which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Programs are designed to provide appropriate knowledge and experiences for credentialing requirements
Information regarding the program is accurate and not misleading
All students are guaranteed employment after graduation
Programs provide current and accurate information about requirements for program completion
The nature and goals of training are specified clearly

questions.explanation: Standard 7.01 requires programs to: be designed to provide appropriate knowledge for credentialing (A); ensure accurate, non-misleading information (B); provide accurate information about program requirements (D); and clearly specify training nature and goals (E). Programs cannot guarantee employment (C) and claiming so would violate Standard 5.01 regarding false or deceptive statements.

questions.stem: Under Standard 7.04 (Student Disclosure of Personal Information), when may a program require students to disclose personal information? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: When the program or training facility has clearly identified this requirement in admissions materials
When the information is necessary to evaluate or obtain assistance for students whose personal problems could impair performance
Whenever a faculty member is curious about a student's personal life
When necessary to prevent a clear and imminent danger to the student or others
When the student's personal problems are affecting their clinical work with clients

questions.explanation: Standard 7.04 permits requiring personal disclosure when: the requirement was identified in admissions materials (A); it is necessary for evaluating or assisting students whose personal problems could compromise competence (B); there is a clear and imminent danger (D); and when personal issues affect clinical work (E, related to protecting clients). Faculty curiosity (C) is never a legitimate basis for requiring personal disclosure.

questions.stem: Standard 7.07 (Sexual Relationships With Students and Supervisees) prohibits sexual relationships with students and supervisees under which conditions? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: When the student or supervisee is in the psychologist's department
When the psychologist has evaluative authority over the student or supervisee
When both parties are consenting adults
When the student or supervisee is likely to be evaluated by the psychologist
When the relationship could exploit the power differential

questions.explanation: Standard 7.07 prohibits sexual relationships with students and supervisees in the psychologist's department, over whom they have evaluative authority, or whom they are likely to evaluate. The power differential inherent in these relationships creates exploitation risk regardless of apparent consent. Consent (C) does not make these relationships ethical because the power imbalance undermines the voluntariness of consent.

questions.stem: A clinical psychology doctoral program is undergoing accreditation review. Under Standard 7.02 (Descriptions of Education and Training Programs), which of the following must be accurately represented? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The program's accreditation status and any conditions on accreditation
Requirements for completion of the program, including practicum hours and dissertation expectations
The program's internship match rates and licensure pass rates, if publicly reported
An inflated job placement rate to attract competitive applicants
The training model, clinical orientations emphasized, and types of practicum settings available

questions.explanation: Standard 7.02 requires that psychologists responsible for education and training programs take reasonable steps to ensure that there is a current and accurate description of the program content, training goals and objectives, stipends and benefits, and requirements that must be met for satisfactory completion. This includes accurate accreditation status (A), completion requirements (B), outcome data if reported (C), and training specifics (E). Inflating job placement rates (D) would violate both Standard 7.02 and Standard 5.01 (Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements).

questions.stem: A supervisor notices that a supervisee has been arriving late to sessions, appears emotionally distraught, and has made several clinical errors in case conceptualization. Under Standards 7.04 and 7.06, which actions are appropriate? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Address the performance concerns directly with the supervisee using established evaluation criteria
Inquire whether personal issues may be affecting the supervisee's professional functioning
Immediately terminate the supervisee from the program without discussion
Provide timely feedback and develop a remediation plan if needed
Recommend that the supervisee seek personal therapy or other support while maintaining the evaluative role

questions.explanation: Standard 7.06 requires evaluation based on established criteria, and Standard 7.04 permits inquiry into personal issues when they may be affecting performance. Appropriate actions include: addressing performance concerns using criteria (A), inquiring about contributing personal factors (B), providing feedback and remediation opportunities (D), and recommending support while maintaining appropriate role boundaries (E). Immediate termination without discussion (C) would violate due process and the spirit of Standards 7.04 and 7.06, which emphasize support, remediation, and fair evaluation.

questions.stem: Match each education and training scenario to the most applicable Standard 7 provision:

rows.text: A training program's brochure claims 100% licensure pass rates when the actual rate is 60%
A professor requires students to attend personal therapy as a program requirement but did not disclose this before admission
A supervisor assigns a student's clinical cases based on the supervisor's personal preferences rather than training needs
A faculty member begins dating a graduate student in their department

columns.text: Standard 7.01: Design of Education and Training Programs
Standard 7.02: Descriptions of Education and Training Programs
Standard 7.04: Student Disclosure of Personal Information
Standard 7.07: Sexual Relationships With Students and Supervisees

questions.explanation: False licensure claims = Standard 7.02 (program descriptions must be accurate and not misleading). Undisclosed therapy requirement = Standard 7.04 (personal disclosure requirements must be identified before admission). Case assignment based on personal preference rather than training = Standard 7.01 (program design should support appropriate training). Dating a departmental student = Standard 7.07 (prohibition on sexual relationships with departmental students).

questions.stem: Match each Standard 7 provision to its primary purpose in protecting student welfare:

rows.text: Standard 7.05: Mandatory Individual or Group Therapy
Standard 7.06: Assessing Student and Supervisee Performance
Standard 7.07: Sexual Relationships With Students and Supervisees

columns.text: Ensuring fair, transparent evaluation based on communicated criteria
Preventing exploitation of inherent power differentials in academic settings
Protecting students from the conflation of evaluative and therapeutic roles
Ensuring students receive current, evidence-based professional training

questions.explanation: Standard 7.03 (Accuracy in Teaching) ensures students receive current, accurate training content (col4). Standard 7.05 (Mandatory Therapy) protects against dual relationships by separating evaluative and therapeutic roles (col3) â€” students must be allowed to choose therapists unaffiliated with the program. Standard 7.06 (Assessment) ensures evaluations are fair and based on pre-communicated criteria (col1). Standard 7.07 (Sexual Relationships) directly addresses the exploitation risk created by power differentials in academic hierarchies (col2).

questions.stem: For each training role, select ALL ethical obligations under Standard 7:

columns.text: Evaluate students based on established, communicated criteria
Address supervisee personal problems that may impair clinical work
Design curriculum to meet credentialing requirements

questions.explanation: Clinical supervisors: Evaluate based on criteria (7.06), address personal problems affecting clinical work (7.04/2.06), and avoid sexual relationships (7.07). Program directors: Evaluate based on criteria (7.06), ensure accurate descriptions (7.02), and design curriculum for credentialing (7.01). Course instructors: Evaluate based on criteria (7.06) and avoid sexual relationships with students (7.07). All roles share the evaluation obligation.

questions.stem: For each Standard 7 scenario, select ALL ethical concerns that apply:

rows.text: A practicum supervisor provides therapy to a student they are also evaluating
A program requires students to role-play personal trauma in class without prior notice
A training director gives a student a failing competency evaluation based on an undisclosed criterion

columns.text: Violation of Standard 7.04 (Student Disclosure of Personal Information)
Violation of Standard 7.05 (Mandatory Individual or Group Therapy)
Violation of Standard 7.06 (Assessing Student and Supervisee Performance)
Violation of Standard 7.02 (Descriptions of Education and Training Programs)

questions.explanation: Scenario 1: A supervisor providing therapy to a student they evaluate violates Standard 7.05 (evaluators should not serve as therapists) and Standard 3.05 (problematic multiple relationship with conflicting roles). Scenario 2: Requiring personal trauma disclosure in class without prior notice violates Standard 7.04 (personal disclosure must be identified in admissions materials) and Standard 7.02 (program/course activities must be accurately described). Scenario 3: Using undisclosed criteria for evaluation violates Standard 7.06 (evaluations must be based on established, communicated criteria) and Standard 7.02 (requirements must be accurately described to students).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 7 (Education and Training):

Psychology programs must ensure that descriptions of their training are [BLANK1] and include current information about requirements for completion. Standard 7.03 requires that course content and teaching methods be described [BLANK2] in course descriptions or syllabi. Programs must not require students to disclose personal information unless the requirement was [BLANK3] in admissions materials, or the information is needed to evaluate students whose personal problems could [BLANK4]. Standard 7.06 requires that student evaluations be based on [BLANK5] that have been communicated to students at the outset.

options: reasonably be judged to prevent effective performance
BLANK4.correct: reasonably be judged to prevent effective performance

questions.explanation: Standard 7: Program descriptions must be accurate and not misleading (7.02). Course content must be described in a timely manner (7.03). Personal disclosure requirements must be identified before admission (7.04). Disclosure may be required when personal problems could prevent effective performance (7.04). Evaluations must be based on established, communicated program requirements (7.06).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Standard 7.05 (Mandatory Individual or Group Therapy):

When individual or group therapy is a program or course requirement, the program must allow students to [BLANK1] from practitioners who are [BLANK2] the program. Faculty who are responsible for [BLANK3] students may not themselves provide that therapy. The primary ethical concern addressed by this standard is the [BLANK4] that arises when one person holds both evaluative and therapeutic power over a student. If a student's personal issues are identified as potentially impairing competence, the program should [BLANK5] rather than directly providing therapy.

options: refer the student to appropriate outside resources
ignore the issue to protect student privacy
BLANK5.correct: refer the student to appropriate outside resources

questions.explanation: Standard 7.05 protects students by requiring that when therapy is mandated, students can select their own therapist from practitioners not associated with the program. Faculty evaluators cannot serve as therapists to those they evaluate, preventing the harmful dual relationship of being both evaluator and therapist. When competence concerns arise from personal issues, programs should refer to outside resources rather than providing therapy directly, maintaining the separation between training evaluation and personal treatment.

questions.stem: A psychology training program discovers that a third-year doctoral student has been struggling with substance use that is affecting their clinical work. The student's practicum supervisor has observed impaired judgment during sessions, including a failure to recognize suicidal ideation in a client. The program must balance the student's welfare against client safety and program obligations.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 7 provision is most directly relevant to the program's obligation to act?

options.text: The student's personal problems are directly impairing clinical competence and client safety
Addressing the issue requires the student to disclose personal information about substance use
The student may face stigma and career consequences from disclosure
The program has no ethical obligation to address student personal issues
Meet with the student to discuss observed performance concerns and the need for evaluation
Develop a remediation plan that may include temporary suspension of clinical duties and referral for treatment
Immediately expel the student without due process to protect clients
Document all observations, communications, and decisions throughout the process

centerOptions.text: Standard 7.01: Design of Education and Training Programs
Standard 7.04: Student Disclosure of Personal Information
Standard 7.06: Assessing Student and Supervisee Performance
Standard 7.07: Sexual Relationships With Students and Supervisees

questions.explanation: Standard 7.06 is most directly relevant because it addresses the program's obligation to evaluate student competence. When a student's performance is impaired to the point of threatening client safety, the program must act under its evaluation mandate. While Standard 7.04 is also implicated (the student may need to disclose personal information), the driving obligation is the competency evaluation under 7.06. Complicating factors include the intersection of personal welfare and professional competence, the need for disclosure, and potential career consequences. Appropriate actions include direct discussion, remediation planning with potential clinical suspension, and thorough documentation. Immediate expulsion without due process would violate procedural fairness.

questions.stem: A newly hired assistant professor in a clinical psychology doctoral program discovers that several program brochures, the department website, and admissions materials contain significantly inflated statistics about internship match rates and job placement outcomes. The program director is aware of the inaccuracies but argues they are necessary to remain competitive with other programs.
questions.centerQuestion: Which Standard 7 provision is most directly violated?

leftColumn.label: Harms Caused by Inaccurate Program Descriptions

options.text: Prospective students make enrollment decisions based on false information
Students who enrolled based on false data may accrue significant debt for a program that does not deliver promised outcomes
The profession's credibility is undermined when training programs misrepresent themselves
Faculty morale improves when programs appear more successful than they are

rightColumn.label: Appropriate Actions for the New Faculty Member

options.text: Document the specific inaccuracies and bring concerns to the program director in writing
If the program director refuses to act, escalate to the department chair, dean, or accrediting body
Ignore the issue because challenging senior faculty could jeopardize the new professor's career
Report the concern through institutional channels such as an ethics committee or ombudsperson

centerOptions.text: Standard 7.01: Design of Education and Training Programs
Standard 7.02: Descriptions of Education and Training Programs
Standard 7.06: Assessing Student and Supervisee Performance

questions.explanation: Standard 7.02 requires psychologists responsible for education and training programs to ensure that there is a current and accurate description of the program content, training goals, stipends, requirements for completion, and basis for granting degrees. Inflating match rates and placement data directly violates this standard and also implicates Standard 5.01 (Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements). The harms are substantial: students make life-altering financial and career decisions based on this information. The new faculty member has an ethical obligation to address the issue through proper channels, even though doing so may be professionally uncomfortable.

questions.stem: A training director is reviewing ethical obligations related to graduate education. Highlight the THREE accurate statements about Standard 7:
questions.passage: (A) Training programs must provide accurate descriptions of program content, training goals, and requirements for completion. (B) Faculty may freely require students to disclose personal information whenever it seems clinically relevant to classroom discussion. (C) Programs have an obligation to evaluate student competence based on established criteria communicated at the outset. (D) Sexual relationships between faculty and students in the same department are permitted if both parties consent. (E) Course instructors must provide timely descriptions of course content and requirements. (F) Programs may dismiss students for any reason without due process. (G) Faculty advisors automatically deserve first authorship on all student publications.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 7.02 requires accurate program descriptions; (C) Standard 7.06 requires evaluation based on established, communicated criteria; (E) Standard 7.03 requires timely description of course requirements. Incorrect: (B) Personal disclosure requirements must be pre-identified in admissions (7.04); (D) Sexual relationships with departmental students are prohibited (7.07); (F) Programs must follow due process; (G) Authorship is based on relative contributions (8.12).

questions.stem: A clinical supervisor is preparing materials on education and training ethics for a supervision seminar. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about Standards 7.04 through 7.07:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 7.04 permits programs to require personal disclosure only if this requirement was identified in admissions materials or the information is needed to evaluate or assist students whose personal problems could prevent effective professional performance. (B) Standard 7.05 allows faculty evaluators to also serve as therapists to students in the program, as long as both roles are clearly defined. (C) Standard 7.06 requires that evaluations of student performance be based on relevant and established program requirements communicated to students at the outset. (D) Standard 7.07 prohibits sexual relationships with students or supervisees in the psychologist's department or over whom the psychologist has or is likely to have evaluative authority. (E) Standard 7.04 permits faculty to require students to disclose personal information at any time if the faculty member believes it would be therapeutically beneficial. (F) Standard 7.05 states that when therapy is a program requirement, students must be allowed to select their own therapist from practitioners not associated with the program. (G) Standard 7.06 allows subjective global impressions to serve as the sole basis for student evaluations. (H) Standard 7.07 permits sexual relationships with students as long as the psychologist has no direct evaluative authority.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Standard 7.04 specifies the limited conditions for requiring personal disclosure; (C) Standard 7.06 mandates evaluation based on established, communicated criteria; (D) Standard 7.07 prohibits sexual relationships with departmental students and those under evaluative authority; (F) Standard 7.05 requires student choice of therapist from non-program practitioners. Incorrect: (B) Evaluators may not serve as therapists (7.05); (E) Faculty cannot require disclosure based on their belief of therapeutic benefit; (G) Subjective impressions alone are insufficient; (H) The prohibition extends to students in the department regardless of direct evaluative authority.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps a psychology training program should follow when a student's personal problems are identified as potentially impairing professional competence, in the correct order:

options.text: Develop a formal written remediation plan with specific behavioral benchmarks and timelines
Identify and document specific observable performance concerns through supervision and evaluation
If remediation is unsuccessful, implement progressive consequences consistent with program policies
Meet with the student to discuss concerns, provide feedback, and explore whether personal issues are contributing
Refer the student to appropriate support resources while clarifying that the program's evaluative role remains separate

questions.explanation: The proper sequence for addressing student competence concerns: First, identify and document specific observable performance problems through formal evaluation channels (Standard 7.06). Then, meet with the student to discuss concerns and explore contributing factors, including personal issues (Standards 7.04/7.06). Next, refer to appropriate support resources while maintaining the evaluative role boundary (Standard 7.05). Develop a formal remediation plan with clear benchmarks. If remediation fails, implement progressive consequences. This sequence balances student welfare with program obligations and client protection.

questions.stem: Arrange the elements of an ethical training program design in the order they should be established, from foundational to implementation:

options.text: Implement fair, transparent evaluation procedures based on the communicated criteria
Define the program's training model, goals, and competency requirements aligned with credentialing standards
Communicate all requirements, including personal disclosure expectations, in admissions materials
Develop accurate program descriptions for recruiting and informational materials
Establish policies for managing student impairment, mandatory therapy requirements, and faculty-student boundaries

questions.explanation: Ethical program design follows a logical sequence: First, define the foundational training model, goals, and competencies needed for credentialing (Standard 7.01). Then, establish program policies addressing student impairment, mandatory therapy (7.05), and boundaries (7.07). Develop accurate descriptions of the program (7.02). Communicate all requirements, including personal disclosure expectations, in admissions materials before students enroll (7.04). Finally, implement fair evaluation procedures that align with communicated criteria (7.06). Each step builds upon the previous one.

questions.stem: A graduate program tracks the types of competence concerns identified in student evaluations across five cohorts:

questions.question: What is the most notable trend in competence concerns over the decade?

options.text: Academic knowledge deficits have become the dominant concern
Interpersonal/professional behavior concerns have overtaken academic knowledge deficits as the primary area of competence problems
All categories have decreased equally
Cultural competence gaps have remained stable

questions.question: What does the increasing emphasis on interpersonal and cultural competence suggest about program evaluation standards?

options.text: Programs should eliminate academic evaluations entirely
Standard 7.06 evaluations have expanded beyond academic knowledge to include professional competencies such as interpersonal skills and cultural responsiveness
These trends reflect a decline in student quality
Programs are being overly demanding in non-academic areas

questions.explanation: The data show a significant shift: interpersonal/professional behavior concerns have risen from 25% to 45%, while academic knowledge deficits have decreased from 45% to 25%. Cultural competence gaps have tripled from 10% to 30%. This reflects the profession's evolving understanding of competence under Standard 7.06, which now encompasses not just knowledge but also professional attitudes, interpersonal effectiveness, and cultural humility. Programs increasingly recognize that clinical competence requires more than academic mastery.

questions.stem: A professional psychology organization tracks student complaints about training program ethics violations over eight years:

questions.question: Which category showed the most concerning increase, and what likely contributed to the spike in 2020-2021?

options.text: Boundary violations increased due to social media
Unfair evaluation complaints spiked, likely reflecting challenges in evaluating student competence during the rapid transition to online education and remote supervision
Program description complaints increased due to new accreditation requirements
All categories increased equally during this period

questions.question: What does the decline in boundary violation complaints suggest?

options.text: Faculty are no longer interested in students
Better training, clearer policies, and increased awareness of Standard 7.07 requirements have been effective prevention measures
Students are afraid to report boundary violations
Boundary violations no longer occur in academic settings

questions.explanation: The data show encouraging declines in program description and boundary violation complaints, suggesting improved compliance with Standards 7.02 and 7.07 through better training and policy implementation. The spike in unfair evaluation complaints (2020-2021) coincides with COVID-19's disruption of traditional evaluation methods, as programs struggled to assess clinical competence through virtual platforms. The subsequent decline suggests adaptation to new evaluation modalities. Overall, the trends indicate that proactive ethics training and policy development under Standard 7 can measurably reduce violations.

questions.stem: Categorize each education/training situation according to the most relevant Standard 7 provision:

categories.label: Standard 7.04: Student Disclosure of Personal Information

items.text: A program website accurately lists accreditation status and internship match rates
A supervisor asks a trainee about personal issues affecting client care after disclosing this possibility at intake
A program evaluates comprehensive exam performance against clearly published rubrics
A brochure claims the program is APA-accredited when it is not
A faculty member requires students to share personal therapy experiences in class without prior notice in the syllabus
A program uses multiple methods (written exams, clinical observations, supervisory ratings) to assess competence

questions.explanation: Standard 7.02 (Program Descriptions): Accurate website listings (item1, compliant) and false accreditation claims (item4, violation). Standard 7.04 (Student Disclosure): Asking about personal issues after disclosure at intake (item2, compliant) and requiring personal sharing without notice (item5, violation). Standard 7.06 (Assessing Performance): Using published rubrics (item3, compliant) and multiple assessment methods (item6, best practice).

questions.stem: Categorize each faculty-student scenario as either ethically permissible or a violation under Standard 7:

items.text: A program requires students to complete personal therapy, allowing them to choose therapists unaffiliated with the program (7.05)
A faculty member begins a romantic relationship with a student in their department (7.07)
A program provides accurate outcome data on its website, including both strengths and areas for improvement (7.02)
A supervisor evaluates a student based solely on the supervisor's subjective feelings about the student's personality (7.06)
A program identifies personal therapy and experiential disclosure requirements in its admissions materials before students enroll (7.04)
A course instructor introduces a new personal journal assignment mid-semester requiring disclosure of trauma history without updating the syllabus or providing prior notice (7.04)

questions.explanation: Permissible: Student-selected therapy from non-program therapists (item1, compliant with 7.05), accurate outcome reporting (item3, compliant with 7.02), and pre-enrollment disclosure of personal requirements (item5, compliant with 7.04). Violations: Faculty-student romantic relationship (item2, violates 7.07), subjective personality-based evaluation (item4, violates 7.06), and mid-semester introduction of trauma disclosure without prior notice (item6, violates 7.04 and 7.03).
